author: Antoine Crochet-Damais
title: Gr33t lÃ¨ve 320 000 euros pour promouvoir une digital workplace plus vertueuse
text:
La plateforme d'analytics incubÃ©e par le cabinet franÃ§ais Lecko incite les collaborateurs Ã  lutter contre l'hyperconnexion et Ã  optimiser leurs Ã©missions de CO2. Un nouvel acteur franÃ§ais de la digital workplace est nÃ©. BaptisÃ© Gr33t, il est incubÃ© par le cabinet de conseil Lecko, un expert parisien spÃ©cialiste du domaine. Gr33t commercialise une solution de gamification visant Ã  promouvoir une utilisation vertueuse des plateformes de communication et de collaboration. La start-up annonce avoir bouclÃ© une levÃ©e de fonds d'amorÃ§age de 320 000 euros. Elle a Ã©tÃ© rÃ©alisÃ©e auprÃ¨s de plusieurs business angels entrepreneurs et acteurs du marchÃ© de la digital workplace : Jean-Pierre Vimard, cofondateur de Powell-Software, Vincent Roullet, SVP customer de Lumapps, Philippe Pinault, cofondateur de Talkspirit, et LoÃ¯c Thomas, CEO de TSM.
Gr33t articule son offre autour d'une application d'analytics taillÃ©e pour Microsoft 365 et Google Workspace. Elle permet Ã  chaque collaborateur et manager de suivre ses pratiques. "C'est un outil qui a Ã©tÃ© dÃ©veloppÃ© sur la base des 15 Ã  20 ans d'expÃ©rience que nous avons auprÃ¨s des grands comptes au sein de Lecko. L'objectif est de proposer une solution qui ait plus d'impact que les mÃ©thodes classiques de conduite du changement principalement orientÃ©es autour de la communication et de la formation", commente Arnaud Rayrole, CEO du cabinet de conseil et co-fondateur deâ€¦

author: @Nilavya1
title: Revolutionizing Coding with Devin: The World's First AI Software Engineer - DEV Community
text: Forget free coffee â˜•ï¸ and ping pong tables ğŸ“, the hottest perk in Silicon Valley might just be your new coworker â€“ Devin, the world's first AI software engineer. But is Devin here to revolutionize coding or steal your paycheck ğŸ‘€? Imagine this:ğŸ¤” You're neck-deep in a complex software project ğŸ¤¯, drowning in repetitive tasks â³ and bug fixesğŸ˜µğŸ’«. Enter Devin, your tireless AI teammate. Devin can churn out code ğŸ‘¨ğŸ’», build websites ğŸŒ, and tackle intricate engineering challenges â€“ all while you focus on the big picture. Sounds like a dream come true ğŸ¤©, right? Although Devin has impressive skills, they are incomparable to the Terminator with a coding degree. Here's the reality: - Devin automates repetitive tasks, freeing up your time to focus on creative problem-solving. Work with Devin to avoid errors and make your job more interesting.ğŸ¤–ğŸ’¼ - Marvel, Devin's AI constantly learns and adapts, becoming a better coder with every project. Think of it as having a coding prodigy by your side, eager to learn from your expertise.ğŸŒŸğŸ‘¨ğŸ’» - Collaboration is key. Devin works well with human engineers by sharing ideas, receiving feedback, and keeping everyone informed. It's like having a coding partner who never needs a nap.ğŸ¤ğŸ‘¨ğŸ’» So, is Devin coming for your job ğŸ‘€? Not likely ğŸ˜®ğŸ’¨ The creators envision Devin as a force multiplier, not a replacement. Think of it as having a super-powered coding assistant who lets you focus on the strategic aspects of software engineering. ğŸ’ªğŸ‘¨ğŸ’» While Devin is a groundbreaking development, AI in software engineering is still young. True human-level creativity and the ability to handle the unexpected are still very much human strengths. ğŸ§ ğŸ› ï¸ But make no mistake, Devin is a sign of things to come. As AI continues to evolve, we can expect even more powerful tools to emerge, ushering in a new era of human-AI collaboration in the world of software engineering. ğŸŒŸğŸš€ The question isn't whether AI will change the coding, it's how. So, buckle up, grab your keyboard âŒ¨ï¸, and get ready to code alongside your new AI teammate. The future of software engineering is here, and it's looking collaborative. ğŸ¤–ğŸ¤ğŸ›

author: Josh Levinson; December
title: Raheem Mostert (ankle) remains out Thursday for Miami
text: Raheem Mostert (ankle) remains out Thursday for Miami Miami Dolphins running back Raheem Mostert (ankle) did not practice again on Thursday for Week 17 versus the Baltimore Ravens. Mostert has been held out of both practices this week while he manages an ankle injury, but he's expected to play on Sunday. De'Von Achane (toe) is also banged up, so Jeff Wilson could see an uptick in snaps and touches against the Ravens. Despite logging a season-low 19 snaps in last week's win over the Dallas Cowboys, Mostert still handled double-digit touches and scored a touchdown. Mostert is the RB25 in numberFire's Week 17 rankings and our models project him for 11.2 FanDuel points, with 11.9 carries, 58.7 rushing yards, 2.0 receptions, and 15.7 receiving yards. The Ravens are allowing the sixth-fewest FanDuel points per game to running backs this season and they have the No. 12 run defense in the NFL, according to our opponent-adjusted efficiency metrics. author: Monica Grant
title: Max Ebb: Rainy Day Projects (Perfect for the Weekend Ahead)
text:
â€œAnother strike against land-based weather forecasts,â€ Lee sighed as we both looked out the windows at torrential rain falling on the docks. I had volunteered to help with youth sailing classes on winter weekends. We would have canceled for the day, but the optimistic forecast that morning promised â€œclear skies by afternoon.â€
Lee was there because she had convinced a traffic court judge that this would count as her required public service after she was busted for blowing through a four-way stop sign on her bike. It was not her first offense.
â€œGet real. I could see there was, like, no cross traffic,â€ she insisted, still annoyed by the whole incident. â€œAnyone can watch that intersection all day, and, like, not a single car comes to a full stop. They all roll through at a safe speed once they see that itâ€™s clear, and I do exactly the same thing, exactly, on my bike. Itâ€™s just that Iâ€™m higher up with a better view and my safe speed is like, a little fasterâ€¦.â€
â€œYouâ€™ll get over it,â€ advised the clubâ€™s official youth sailing instructor, recalling his grandfatherâ€™s advice about traffic tickets from the distant past: â€œJust pay the two dollars.â€
â€œIf it were still two dollars,â€ Lee complained.
â€œBut our immediate problem,â€ I reminded her over our lunch of expertly prepared macaroni and cheese, â€œis that we have to come up with indoor activities for all these restless young sailors. I guess we could do another knot-tying session.â€
â€œWe did sailing knots last week,â€ the instructor reminded us. â€œAnd frankly, they seemed a little bored even then.â€
â€œBut the weather was perfect for sailing last week,â€ Lee recalled.
â€œRight, the weather was perfect last week; the kids could have been out on the water all day. My bad.â€ The youth instructor was a college student and a great sailor, always in demand as big-boat crew.
â€œYouâ€™ll get over it,â€ Lee returned the instructorâ€™s advice.
â€œRemember what they say about tacticians,â€ I added, seeing no need to give this kid a break. â€œYouâ€™re only as good as your last call.â€
â€œAll right, hereâ€™s what we can do today,â€ the instructor suggested after watching the rain for another minute. â€œPaper boats. We can float them on the puddles in the parking lot.â€
â€œEven better,â€ said Lee, â€œletâ€™s teach them to make paper self-righting lifeboats. A little more complex than your basic paper boat, but they demonstrate the significance of the roll metacenter: Itâ€™s at the center of the rocker radius, a virtual center of rotation of a floating object. And if itâ€™s below the center of gravity, the boat will be unstable in roll, and if the boat is placed upside down on the table, the boat will right itself.â€
The self-righting paper boat. [ If you try it this weekend, let us know how it went. ] Â© 2024 Max Ebb â€œDo you have the instructions memorized?â€ I asked.
â€œNo, but I know where to find them.â€
